items.description: The Technology's Division's Resource Repository is sponsored by the following companies and organizations.
items.title: Sponsors

items.description:
Data resources that are publicly available for use. Licenses may apply.
Open Data Sites and national scale datasets should be near the top of each section.
items.title: Public Data Resources

items.description: Vendors that can provide purchased or licensed data for a variety of uses.
items.title: Vendor Data Resources

items.description: A collection of urban planning related data specifications and standards for use as part of programs & projects.
items.title: Planning Data Specifications

items.description: The CityGML standard defines a conceptual model and exchange format for the representation, storage and exchange of virtual 3D city models. It enables an interdisciplinary common operating platform for civic systems.
items.title: CityGML

items.description: The  Land Based Classification Standards classifies land uses across five dimensions (Activity, Function, Structure, Site, and Ownership).
items.title: LBCS

items.description: The Digital Twins Definition Language is the language by which developers can define the language of the entities they expect to use in their topologies.
items.title: DTDL

items.description: The BLDS data standard is a collaborative effort by civic technology companies, governments and other interested parties to create a shared data specification for building and construction permit data.
items.title: BLDS

items.description: The House Facts data standard is a uniform format for reporting government data on the operation, safety, and performance of residential buildings.
items.title: HouseFacts

items.description: A standardized, digital description of the built environment, including buildings and civil infrastructure. It is an open, international standard (ISO 16739-1:2018).
items.title: IFC

items.description: Referencing System is a global, non-proprietary linear referencing system for describing streets maintained by SharedStreets. Additional Information:
items.title: SharedStreets

items.description: An open data specification for curb regulations maintained by SharedStreets. Additional Information: , Demo: Interactive , Blog post: .
items.title: CurbLR

items.description: The Curb Data Specification provides data specifications for curb regulations alongside a connected event and metrics API intended to help cities manage their curb zone programs and surrounding areas, and measure the utilization and impact.
items.title: CDS

items.description: The General Transit Feed Specification is a popular standard for describing transit systems.
items.title: GTFS

items.description: A data format that models flexible public transportation services (microtransit/paratransit) as an extension to GTFS.
items.title: GTFS-flex

items.description: This standard provides users transit data updates in real time greatly enhances their experience of transit services.
items.title: GTFS-RT

items.description: Network Timetable Exchange is a European standard to exchange standardized time tables and other system characteristics used to describe transit systems.
items.title: NeTEx

items.description: Service Interface for Real Time Information (SIRI) is a European standard for real-time information which has had limited adoption in the United States, but would be compatible with hardware and network systems which meet European standards.
items.title: SIRI

items.description: A data specification for representing street right of ways.
items.title: shared-row

items.description: A data specification for routable pedestrian networks and describing and sharing pedestrian network and pedestrian network-adjacent data.
items.title: OpenSidewalks

items.description: The General Bikeshare Feed Specification is a standardized data feed for shared mobility system availability.
items.title: GBFS

items.description: The Mobility Data Specification is a data standard to enable communication between mobility companies and local governments.
items.title: MDS

items.description: The Managed and Tolled Lanes Feed Specification is intended to be used by the managed lanes and toll industry for the standardization and sharing of dynamic toll rates, and any managed lane purpose including but not limited to, ramp metering, bus only lanes, express lanes, especially if the resources are being priced dynamically.
items.title: MTLFS

items.description: The General Modeling Network Specification defines a common human and machine readable format for sharing routable road network files.
items.title: GMNS

items.description: The data that is stored in an ASAM OpenDRIVE file describes the geometry of roads, lanes and objects, such as roadmarks on the road, as well as features along the roads, like signals.
items.title: OpenDrive

items.description: This is a curated list of Python, R, or other open-source libraries or programming tools can be useful for urban planning applications.
items.title: Planning Coding Resources

items.description: Python Libraries & Related Resources.
Flexible and powerful data analysis / manipulation library for Python, providing labeled data structures similar to R data.frame objects, statistical functions, and much more.
items.title: Pandas

items.description: A Python site package that provides a useful and productive way to perform geographic data analysis, data conversion, data management, and map automation with Python.
items.title: Arcpy

items.description: The ArcGIS API for Python is a powerful, modern and easy to use Pythonic library to perform GIS visualization and analysis, spatial data management and GIS system administration tasks that can run both interactively, and using scripts. This library enables easy use of Pandas within the ArcGIS platform.
items.title: ArcGIS Python API

items.description: An open source project to make working with geospatial data in Python easier. GeoPandas extends the datatypes used by Pandas to allow spatial operations on geometric types.
items.title: Geopandas

items.description: A Python 3.6+ library for working with GTFS feeds using Pandas DataFrames.
items.title: Partridge

items.description: Helps explore GTFS data and their network characteristics.
items.title: Peartree

items.description: Urban network analysis library intended to help planners compute quick accessibility metrics or shortest paths. Additional Information: License: AGPL-3.0 License: Provider: UrbanSim Inc. (UDST).
items.title: Pandana

items.description: A platform for building statistical models of cities and regions. These models help forecast long-range patterns in real estate development, demographics, and related outcomes, under various policy scenarios. Information: License: BSD License: Provider: UrbanSim Inc. (UDST).
items.title: UrbanSim

items.description: Geospatial & temporal neighborhood analysis using US Census Data.
items.title: Geosnap

items.description: Python for street networks. Retrieve, model, analyze, and visualize street networks and other spatial data from OpenStreetMap.
items.title: OSMnx

items.description: This is a package of classes and functions to streamline the representation and analysis of urban networks. This library includes a Python implementation of the Urban Network Analysis Tools.
items.title: Madina

items.description: Provides a set of tools to scrape bike sharing data from different websites and APIs, thus providing a coherent and generalized set of classes and methods to access this sort of information.
items.title: Pybikes

items.description: A free and open-source Python package that enables users to analyze and visualize geospatial data with minimal coding in a Jupyter environment. Leafmap's interactive GUI allows no code layer management and analysis including a powerful analytical backend (i.e., ). Additional Information: , , .
items.title: Leafmap

items.description: A small set of Python functions to draw pretty maps from OpenStreetMap data.
items.title: Prettymaps

items.description: A library that provides a Python interface to HERE APIs.
items.title: HerePy

items.description: A Python package that crawls the traffic flow data of your favorite routes, cities by using the API provided by HERE.
items.title: StreetTraffic

items.description: The Python Spatial Analysis Library is a collection of algorithms for exploring spatial correlations and other spatial relationships.
items.title: PySAL

items.description: A package for pedestrian-scale network-based urban analysis: network analysis, urban morphology, land use, accessibility, and statistical aggregations.
items.title: city-seer-api

items.description: A Python package for interactive mapping with Google Earth Engine, ipyleaflet, and ipywidgets.
items.title: Geemap

items.description: A high-level Python geospatial plotting library. It is an extension to cartopy and Matplotlib which makes mapping easy: like Seaborn for geospatial.
items.title: Geoplot

items.description: A plotting library inspired by R-Shiny to create interactive plots.
items.title: Gleam

items.description: The urbansprawl project provides an open source framework for assessing urban sprawl using open data. It uses OpenStreetMap (OSM) data to calculate its sprawling indices, divided in Accessibility, Land use mix, and Dispersion.
items.title: Urbansprawl

items.description: Implements common raster analysis functions using Numba and provides an easy-to-install, easy-to-extend codebase for raster analysis.
items.title: Xarray-spatial

items.description: A library for quantitative analysis of urban form - urban morphometrics. It is part of PySAL (Python Spatial Analysis Library) and is built on top of GeoPandas, other PySAL modules and networkX.
items.title: Momepy

items.description: Geographic information systems use GeoTIFF and other formats to organize and store gridded raster datasets such as satellite imagery and terrain models.
items.title: rasterio

items.description: An open source Python package to process large urban environments mapped with LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) data. As of v0.1.6, focuses on tree extraction.
items.title: TerraVide

items.description: An open source Python library for building interactive data visualizations on the web. It enables you to build custom data dashboards using pure Python.
items.title: Dash

items.description: An open source library for simplifying the structure of street networks.
items.title: Neatnet
Python

items.description: R Packages & Related Resources.
Create dynamic, web-friendly visualizations of data using R. Additional Information: .
items.title: R Shiny

items.description: Support for simple features, a standardized way to encode spatial vector data in R.
items.title: simplefeatures(sf)

items.description: Resource for plotting a wide range of data (useful for visualizing survey data). Additional Information: GNU GENERAL PUBLIC LICENSE.
items.title: ggplot2

items.description: Go-to library for text mining--often used in tandem with ggplot or other text mining libraries.
items.title: tidytext

items.description: R package for fast web-gl rendering for leaflet maps.
items.title: leafgl

items.description: Describes spatial patterns of categorical raster data for any defined regular and irregular areas. It enables spatial analysis such as search, change detection, and clustering to be performed on spatial patterns.
items.title: Motif

items.description: Reading, writing, manipulating, analyzing and modeling of spatial data. The package implements basic and high-level functions for raster data and for vector data operations such as intersections.
items.title: Raster

items.description: Is an R binding package for calling Google Earth Engine API from within R. Various functions are implemented to simplify the connection with the R spatial ecosystem.
items.title: Rgee

items.description: Is an R package for rapid realistic routing on multimodal transport networks (walk, bike, public transport and car) leveraging the Conveyal R5 routing engine.
items.title: r5r

items.description: Provides a tidy approach to spatial network analysis.
items.title: Sfnetworks

items.description: Reading, manipulating, writing and plotting spatiotemporal arrays (raster and vector data cubes) in 'R'.
items.title: Stars

items.description: Tools for transport planning with an emphasis on spatial transport data and non-motorized modes including OD data processing and other functions.
items.title: stplanr

items.description: Thematic maps are geographical maps in which spatial data distributions are visualized. This package offers a flexible, layer-based, and easy to use approach to create thematic maps, such as choropleths and bubble maps.
items.title: Tmap

items.description: A tidy approach to accessing and manipulating GTFS data, including transit routes, schedules, and stops.
items.title: tidytransit

items.description: A tidy approach to accessing data from the US Census Bureau API for manipulation or spatial analysis.
items.title: tidycensus
R

items.description: Other coding special projects and/or other resources.
Common patterns and anti-patterns for civic tech and civic applications. Additional Information: Provided by Code for America.
items.title: civic-tech-patterns

items.description: Case study projected dedicated to developing global healthy and sustainable city-indicators collaboration.
items.title: global-indicators
Other

items.description: Front-end web related packages and resources.
Widely-used, well documented library for quick design and customization of websites. Additional Information: .
items.title: Bootstrap

items.description: Create simple (or advanced) visualizations of data for web and mobile. Additional Information: .
items.title: Chart.js

items.description: Open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps. Plugins available to extend functionality (e.g., storymaps, heatmaps, animation). Additional Information: .
items.title: Leaflet

items.description: Advanced geospatial analysis for browsers and Node.js. Additional Information: .
items.title: Turf.js

items.description: JavaScript library for working with GTFS data. Additional Information: Unlicense: WSDOT.
items.title: GTFS-Js
Web and JS

items.description: Software and platforms for planners and those interested in the built environment.
items.title: Platforms and Software Resources

items.description: Collections of planning related literature, information aggregators, or similar resources.
items.title: Educational and Informational Resources

items.description: Other types of planning data & technology resources. They are a good source of inspiration to contribute to this repo for example, but we don't need to duplicate efforts.
items.title: Other Resources

items.description: This page is registered as an awesome-list, but similar GitHub repositories can be listed here. These are managed curations of resources that relate to different topics.
A collection of transit data tools and resources.
items.title: awesome-transit

items.description: A collection of micromobility tools and data resources.
items.title: micromobility-tools-and-resources

items.description: A curated list of open technology projects to sustain a stable climate, energy supply, and vital natural resources.
items.title: awesome-sustainable-technology

items.description: Awesome GIS is a collection of geospatial related sources, including cartographic tools, geoanalysis tools, developer tools, data, conference & communities, news, massive open online course, some amazing map sites, and more.
items.title: awesome-gis

items.description: Open source technology for agriculture, farming, and gardening.
items.title: awesome-agriculture

items.description: GeoJSON utilities that will make your life easier.
items.title: awesome-geojson

items.description: Review of the generative AI landscape including tools/utilities.
items.title: ai-collection
Other GitHub Resource Lists

items.description:
If you don't have a GitHub, but have a resources that falls into the categories below you would like to contribute try putting the information in this Google Sheet here. We will look at incorporating it into the repository pending review.
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfGp_XC5V-uIzafsVBhR4xKX9YhgNOz22w84Sg0zo0ONDdV4w/viewform?usp=sf_link
items.title: Form Based Contributions

items.description: We are actively looking for contributions from those interested in urban planning and technology. To find out more, visit the Contribution page to see our recommended format. For large contributions, file an issue first. The advantage of contributing to the repo in this manner is that your addition to this shared resource will be recorded.
items.title: GitHub Contributions

items.description:
Similar to other resources aggregators, this repository is released into CC 1.0. We do not require citation, but in order to generate more contributions for and understanding of this resource we do appreciate sharing this repository or citing it where appropriate.
If you do cite this repository you can as:
urban-and-regional-planning-resources. (2020) APA Technology Division. Taken from: from https://github.com/APA-Technology-Division
items.title: License and Citation
